summary:
I'm an experienced computer science lecturer, researcher, and programmer with a focus on game technology. As a lecturer, I love teaching people how to think in terms of data structures and algorithms, usually applied to geometry and games. As a researcher, I'm interested in crowd simulation, AI, VR, and computational geometry. 

In 2017, I obtained my PhD at Utrecht University (The Netherlands), where I continued as a lecturer for courses such as Game programming, Crowd simulation, and Geometric algorithms. In 2019, I became a postdoctoral researcher at Inria Rennes (France). At both institutes, I have developed real-time crowd simulation frameworks in C++, which are being used by researchers and in the industry. I'm also the main author of the second edition of "Learning C# by Programming Games", a book used by universities and hobbyists alike.

In November 2021, I joined Breda University of Applied Sciences (The Netherlands) as a lecturer in the "Creative Media and Game Technologies" programme. I'm mostly teaching second-year programming students, helping them create custom game engines together.

Next to this, I develop mobile apps and games in a two-man company. We are currently working in Xamarin Forms and Unity.

I like to work precisely and efficiently, but I also enjoy adding artistic and humorous touches whenever possible. Not only does this make every task infinitely more enjoyable for myself; I am confident that it also helps at keeping students, players, and users engaged.

awards.title: Pluim (Game Programming 2018-2019)
awards.description: I was awarded a "Pluim" for my efforts in improving and teaching the Game Programming course of our BSc programme.
awards.issuer: Utrecht University, Department of Information and Computing Sciences

projects.title: Beter Spellen, Beter Rekenen, and NU Beter Engels for Android / iOS
projects.description: Orange Gears has created mobile apps for Beter Spellen, Beter Rekenen, and NU Beter Engels. Published by Noordhoff Uitgevers BV, these apps provide users with daily tests of four questions on Dutch spelling, math, and English. The content of these apps is provided by their corresponding websites. The apps are avaliable for free on Android and iOS devices.

contributors.headline: Co-founder of Orange Gears | Developer at Indocs

projects.title: Beter Afrikaans for Android / iOS
projects.description: Orange Gears has created the mobile app for Beter Afrikaans, a website that helps people improve their Afrikaans spelling and grammar by presenting daily tests of four questions. The app extends the website by providing a convenient way to perform the daily test on Android and iOS devices. The app is available for free.

contributors.headline: Co-founder of Orange Gears | Developer at Indocs

projects.title: UMANS (crowd simulation software)
projects.description: UMANS (Unified Microscopic Agent Navigation Simulator) is open crowd-simulation software that can reproduce many different algorithms for collision avoidance. UMANS translates these algorithms to a single principle, while unifying as many simulation details as possible. This makes it a suitable platform for honest comparisons between crowd-simulation algorithms.

projects.title: Explicit Corridor Map (navigation mesh)
projects.description: The Explicit Corridor Map (ECM) software creates a 2D and 3D multi-layered navigation mesh for path planning and crowd simulation purposes.

projects.title: Stample
projects.description: Stample is a location-based mobile game for Android, in which users can collect virtual stamps by visiting interesting real-world locations. The app launched in the Netherlands in April 2014.

profile_positions.description: Lecturer involved in the two Games programs of BUas: the bachelor "Creative Media and Game Technologies" (Programming track) and the master "Game Technology".
profile_positions.title: Lecturer

profile_positions.description:
App and game development. Website: https://www.orangegears.nl/

In 2014, we have published Stample, a location-based game for Android devices.

In 2015, we have started developing Android and iOS apps for the "Beter Spellen" family of websites, which includes Beter Afrikaans, Beter Spellen, Beter Rekenen, and NU Beter Engels.

In 2016, we have released Beter Spellen, Beter Rekenen, and NU Beter Engels under publication of Noordhoff Uitgevers. We have published the other apps as Orange Gears.

In 2018, we have released major updates of all "Beter" apps, with an improved design and additional features.
profile_positions.title: Co-Founder

profile_positions.description:
Researcher on crowd simulation, in the group of Dr Julien Pettré. 
Part of the RAINBOW team: https://team.inria.fr/rainbow/

I have written articles on various aspects of crowd simulation, such as high-density crowd simulation using fluid dynamics, and synchronization between global path planning and local collision avoidance.

I am also the main author of UMANS, Inria's open-source crowd simulation software.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
As a lecturer, I've taught the following courses:
- Geometric algorithms (MSc, April 2017 - July 2017)
- Game programming (BSc, September 2017 - November 2017)
- Crowd simulation (MSc, November 2017 - February 2018)
- Research methods (BSc, February 2018 - April 2018)
- Game programming (BSc, September 2018 - November 2018)

I've also been a tutor/supervisor of several student groups at BSc level, and the MSc thesis supervisor of a number of "Game and Media Technology" students.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer (Docent)

profile_positions.description:
From January 2016 to March 2017, I have worked as a scientific programmer on our crowd simulation framework for an STW Demonstrator project.

In this project, I have improved the software that originated from my MSc and PhD research. I focused on generating robust navigation meshes in 2D and multi-layered environments. I have also helped redesign our crowd simulation engine to support e.g. dynamic environments and interaction via an API. As an example, we have integrated our software as a plug-in into Unity3D.
profile_positions.title: ICT Developer

profile_positions.description:
Department of Information and Computing Sciences, Virtual Worlds division.

Thesis title: Navigation for Characters and Crowds in Complex Virtual Environments.
I defended my thesis on March 30, 2017.

Teaching activities:
- 2013/14, 14/15, 15/16: Logic for computer science (INFOB1LI), exercise seminar leader
- 2013/14, 14/15, 15/16: Path planning (INFOMPAP), workshops
- 2014/15, 15/16: Algorithmics (INFOAL), exercise seminar leader
- 2015/16: Geometric algorithms (INFOGA), homework assignments
profile_positions.title: PhD Student

profile_positions.description: Development of crowd simulation software, continued from my internship.
profile_positions.title: Junior Simulation Engineer

profile_positions.description:
Development of new algorithms for a multi-layered navigation mesh and density-based crowd simulation.
Implementation of my own MSc thesis concepts in C++; integration with Incontrol’s pedestrian simulation tool.
profile_positions.title: Intern (Software Developer)

profile_positions.description:
Assistance at various "werkcolleges" in the BSc Computer Science curriculum.

- 2008/2009: Mathematical techniques for computer science (INFOWIS)
- 2008/2009 and 2009/2010: Data structures (INFODS)
- 2009/2010: Statistics (INFOSTAT)
- 2009/2010: Logic and set theory (INFOLV)
profile_positions.title: Student Teaching Assistant
